title: Debt & Obligations
description: Explore your feelings about debt and financial commitments.

questions.text: My overall feeling about debt is...
choices: Avoid it whenever possible
It's a tool—depends on how you use it
Some debt is just part of life
It makes me uncomfortable regardless

therapeutic.rationale: Debt attitudes are deeply emotional and often inherited. Avoiders see it as dangerous; tool-users see it strategically; accepters see it as normal; uncomfortable types have anxiety regardless of logic. These feelings shape major decisions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different debt attitudes can clash on mortgages, education loans, car purchases. The avoider may feel the tool-user is reckless; the tool-user may feel the avoider is limiting. Understand the feeling beneath the position.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared debt attitudes make major decisions easier. You'll naturally agree on when debt is acceptable.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What did your family teach you about debt—explicitly or implicitly? How does that show up now?

questions.text: When it comes to paying off debt, I prefer to...
choices: Attack it aggressively—get it gone
Pay it down steadily while living life
Focus on high-interest debt first
Whatever minimizes stress

therapeutic.rationale: Debt payoff strategy reveals values and anxiety levels. Aggressive payers want freedom fast; steady payers want balance; strategic payers optimize; stress-minimizers prioritize peace. Partners may have different approaches.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The aggressive payer may feel the steady payer isn't taking it seriously; the steady payer may feel the aggressive payer is sacrificing too much. Find the pace that works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared payoff philosophy makes tackling debt easier. You'll naturally agree on the approach.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when you think about debt you have (or might have)? What would paying it off change?

questions.text: Financial obligations (loans, bills, commitments) make me feel...
choices: Responsible—I take them seriously
Weighed down—they're always on my mind
Neutral—they're just part of life
Motivated to reduce them

therapeutic.rationale: How obligations feel emotionally varies. Responsible-feelers take them in stride; weighed-down types carry anxiety; neutral types aren't bothered; motivated types want freedom. These feelings affect quality of life.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The weighed-down partner may need more reassurance; the neutral partner may not understand the anxiety. Take your partner's emotional experience seriously.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared emotional experience with obligations means you understand each other's relationship with commitments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do financial obligations affect your daily mood? Do they weigh on you or fade into the background?

questions.text: Before taking on new debt or obligations, I need...
choices: To be certain we can handle it
To understand why it's worth it
To talk it through together
To feel like we have no other choice

therapeutic.rationale: What you need before committing reveals decision-making values. Certainty-seekers need safety; worth-understanders need justification; talkers need partnership; no-choice types are reluctant. These needs affect major decisions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs may clash when decisions arise. The certainty-seeker may feel the worth-understander is too willing; the worth-understander may feel the certainty-seeker is too cautious.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared needs make taking on obligations easier to navigate. You'll naturally align on the process.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a financial obligation you've taken on. What did you need to feel okay about it?

questions.text: The conversation I'd want us to have about any debt is...
choices: How to get out of it as fast as possible
How it fits into our bigger picture
How we both feel about it
What we can learn from it

therapeutic.rationale: Debt conversations can focus on action, strategy, feelings, or growth. Fast-escapers want plans; big-picture thinkers want context; feeling-focusers want emotional processing; learners want meaning. All approaches have value.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The fast-escaper may feel the feeling-focuser is stalling; the feeling-focuser may feel the fast-escaper is dismissive. Make room for both practical and emotional conversations.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conversation focus means you'll approach debt discussions the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: If you had (or have) debt, what would you most want to talk about with your partner?
